'''Unity''' is a [[Shell (computing)|shell interface]] for the [[GNOME]] [[desktop environment]] developed by [[Canonical Ltd]] for its [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu operating system]]. Unity debuted in the [[Ubuntu Netbook Edition|netbook edition]] of [[Ubuntu 10.10]]. It is designed to make more efficient use of space given the limited screen size of [[netbook]]s, including, for example, a vertical application switcher<ref>{{cite web |last=Proffitt |first=Brian |title=Ubuntu Unity Interface Tailored for Netbook Screens |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/196009/ubuntu_unity_interface_tailored_for_netbook_screens.html?tk=mod_rel |publisher=ITWorld |accessdate=28 October 2010 |date=2010-05-10}}</ref> called the launcher.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://help.ubuntu.com/11.04/ubuntu-help/unity-introduction.html |title=Welcome to Ubuntu 11.04 |work=Ubuntu Official Documentation |publisher=Ubuntu documentation team |accessdate=2011-06-13 }}</ref> Unlike GNOME, [[KDE Software Compilation]], or [[Xfce]], Unity is not a collection of applications but designed to be used with existing [[GTK+]] programs.<ref name=UbuntuSplits>{{cite web |last=Jackson |first=Joab |title=Software / Services Oct 25, 2010 1:20 pm Canonical Ubuntu Splits From GNOME Over Design Issues |url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/208708/canonical_ubuntu_splits_from_gnome_over_design_issues.html |publisher=PC World Business Center |accessdate=28 October 2010 |date=2010-10-25}}</ref> Unity can be viewed as a shell for GNOME.
+
'''Unity''' is a [[Shell (computing)|shell interface]] for the [[GNOME]] [[desktop environment]] developed by [[Canonical Ltd]] for its [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu operating system]]. Unity debuted in the [[Ubuntu Netbook Edition|netbook edition]] of [[Ubuntu 10.10]]. It is designed to make more efficient use of space given the limited screen size of [[netbook]]s, including, for example, a vertical application switcher<ref>{{cite web |last=Proffitt |first=Brian |title=Ubuntu Unity Interface Tailored for Netbook Screens |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/196009/ubuntu_unity_interface_tailored_for_netbook_screens.html?tk=mod_rel |publisher=ITWorld |accessdate=28 October 2010 |date=2010-05-10}}</ref> called the launcher.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://help.ubuntu.com/11.04/ubuntu-help/unity-introduction.html |title=Welcome to Ubuntu 11.04 |work=Ubuntu Official Documentation |publisher=Ubuntu documentation team |accessdate=2011-06-13 }}</ref> Unlike GNOME, [[KDE Software Compilation]], or [[Xfce]], Unity is not a collection of applications but designed to be used with existing [[GTK+]] programs.<ref name=UbuntuSplits>{{cite web |last=Jackson |first=Joab |title=Software / Services Oct 25, 2010 1:20 pm Canonical Ubuntu Splits From GNOME Over Design Issues |url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/208708/canonical_ubuntu_splits_from_gnome_over_design_issues.html |publisher=PC World Business Center |accessdate=28 October 2010 |date=2010-10-25}}</ref>
Unity is part of the Ayatana project, an initiative to improve the user experience within Ubuntu. In addition to Unity, there are Application Indicators and other projects such as MeMenu, the notification system and the application NotifyOSD gathered.
Unity is part of the Ayatana project, an initiative to improve the user experience within Ubuntu. In addition to Unity, there are Application Indicators and other projects such as MeMenu, the notification system and the application NotifyOSD gathered.
